page.title: 08EYEMOUTH TAPESTRY
page.content: {THE EYEMOUTH TAPESTRY} On display in the local museum is the Eyemouth Tapestry, measuring 15ft x 3ft it was commissioned to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Great Fishing Disaster of 1881 when half the fleet and 129 men were lost, many in sight of the shore. The tapestry was designed by Alistair .I. Scott, sewn by 24 local women using coloured threads, tapestry wool and gold threads. It took 2 years to complete. It consists of 5 panels, the first 3 illustrate the tragic events which occured that day, the last two depict the equipment which helps to ensure the safety of fishermen today. The name panels list the names of each boat and man that was lost. The tapestry was completed in 1981, the same year that the Eyemouth Museum was opened.
